awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel High Voltage Pulsed Power Supplies for Nanosecond Repetitively Pulsed Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a medical device that accelerates wound healing and prevents infection.  Wound contamination and infection are notoriously challenging to treat and are a significant cause of patient morbidity and mortality. Bacterial and other microbial colonization in wounds delay healing, cause further degradation, and can lead to severe complications including deep tissue and bone infections, as well as stroke and sepsis. The wound care field is large and diverse and includes acute and chronic wounds, pre- and post-surgical care and scar prevention, burns, as well as emergency wound care in war settings and homeland security. Due to the aging population and increasing rates of diabetes and obesity, the entire global wound care products market is expanding rapidly at an estimated 7% per year and currently totals over $21B. Moreover, new financial reimbursement policies to reduce the estimated $50B US economic burden of wounds are incentivizing hospitals to improve care, reduce infection, and accelerate patient recovery. The market is ripe for a medical technology that treats wound infections.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project supports the development of a high voltage power supply capable of driving a cold plasma medical device that treats wound infections. Cold plasma is ideal for treating wound infections because it is effective against all bacteria types and is unlikely to confer bacterial resistance. It is superior in its anti-microbial effect compared to topical antibiotics and antiseptics but safe for human skin. Our research objectives include scaling the output voltage, shortening pulse width, enabling thermal, overvoltage, and overcurrent protections, and incorporating voltage control feedback. Anticipated technical results include completion of these research objectives and testing of the power supply with the cold plasma device on bacterial cultures to confirm antibacterial effects.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The key objective of this project was to develop a small, low cost, high voltage power supply capable of driving Airity Technologies’ Nanosecond Repetitivele Pulsed (NRP) plasma.

NRP plasma is a cold (room temperature) atmospheric pressure plasma that is generated from air using short high voltage pulses of electricity. The antimicrobial properties of NRP plasma may be used to reduce the bacterial load in chronic wounds to promote healing, reduce treatment cost, and prevent serious complications such as amputation. For the plasma to be effective and remain cold, the high voltage pulses must be greater than 10 kV and shorter than about 200 ns. Before the start of this project, the only power supplies available that could generate NRP plasma cost over $50,000 and weighed about 60 lbs. An initial market analysis indicated that conventional power supplies are too large and expensive to be incorporated into a device that could be adopted by a wide range of healthcare providers.

Several versions of the high voltage power supply were designed, fabricated, and tested. Trade-offs on operating frequency, semi-conductor selection, and topology were analyzed. Designs were evaluated in the circuit analysis program Spice, and the best designs were implemented in printed circuit board (PCB) and tested.

 

A portable, battery powered NRP device was designed and built around the newly developed power supply and the following milestones were achieved:

1) DC output voltage of 40 kV was achieved as well as greater than 20 kV pulses

2) Pulse widths of 30-40 ns were demonstrated

3) Power supply cost was optimized to less than $200

4) Input power was reduced from 1500 watts to 25 watts allowing battery operation

5) Mass was reduced by 100x allowing the power supply to be incorporated into a handheld device.

The NRP device, powered by the new power supply, was also used to assess the safety and preliminary efficacy in animal trials with mice, and in a proof-of concept clinical trial the usability and safety was evaluated in healthy volunteers. In addition to our own plasma developments, we worked together with other companies to successfully implement our design for environmental and medical plasma applications. The collaborations led to two sales already and work towards future research and development efforts.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2017
Modified by: Luke C Raymond
